Award.AwardTitle: Computational and Experimental Design of Novel CoNiGa High Temperature Shape Memory Alloys
Award.AbstractNarration: TECHNICAL: Shape memory alloys (SMAs) are an important class of smart materials that can produce large recoverable shape changes as a result of reversible martensitic phase transformations, which can be triggered by changes in temperature, stress or magnetic field. Currently, practical uses for SMAs are limited to temperatures below 1000 C, i.e. the transformation temperature (TT) limits of NiTi binary and Cu?]based systems, the most successful SMAs to date. Recently, SMAs based on the CoNiAl/Ga systems have shown promising characteristics, such as broad range of TT control through compositional adjustments, cheaper constituents than Pd, Pt, and Au used in NiTiX high temperature SMAs (HTSMAs), higher thermal stability, and less affinity to oxygen/carbon. Moreover, the fact that a third, hard, ordered phase is often at equilibrium with the transformable phases, offers the possibility of forming nanocomposites to improve the cyclic stability, creep susceptibility, and shape memory (SM) properties of such alloys. The ultimate goal of the current work is to develop CoNiGa HTSMAs through a combined computational/experimental approach. The specific objectives are to: 1) maximize TTs through computational/experimental composition optimization of the high symmetry transformable phase; 2) determine the phase equilibria to find optimal compositions and temperatures at which three?]phase systems can be found; 3) design heat treatment schedules through predicted/experimentally determined kinetics of the precipitation/dissolution of secondary phases; 4) fabricate and characterize the SM and PE responses of single crystals as a function of distribution and amount of secondary phases and crystallographic orientation; 5) explore the selection of hard nanoprecipitate variants through constrained aging and their effects on cyclic stability and creep of SM properties; and 6) demonstrate improved formability of polycrystalline CoNiGa HTSMAs in the presence of ductile secondary phases. The scientific merits of this transformative research are: (a) the potential of revolutionizing the field of HTSMAs, by moving away from current expensive, unstable and brittle materials to HTSMAs possessing high thermal stability, low susceptibility to creep, aging and cyclic damage as well as good ductility to improve the formability of polycrystals for transportation, aerospace, and public utility applications.; (b) transformation of the design process for new HTSMAs through the synergistic experimental computational approach; (c) the creation of an entirely new family of SMAs, i.e. shape memory superalloys, with very high temperature (500?]7000C) SM and PE properties. NON-TECHNICAL: The broader impacts of the activities are reflected in the following areas: (a) maintaining US leading role in active materials research despite the vast amount of recent works at overseas on SMAs; (b) development of teaching modules for incorporation into undergraduate courses; (c) helping K-12 students in developing science projects with SMAs; (d) enriched graduate and undergraduate research experiences in coordination with the new IGERT and Nanomaterials certificate programs; (e) development of a graduate course in computational materials science; (e) involvement of underrepresented groups; (f) disseminating the knowledge generated to both academia and industry through the presentations, publications, and a website, and (g) close collaboration with industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Shape memory alloys (SMAs) are a class of smart materials that reversibly change their shape upon the application of temperature, stress and/or magnetic fields.This phenomenon is called the 'shape memory effect'. At the same time, SMAs have the ability of deform substantially and yet return to their original configuration after the load is released. This phenomenon is called the 'super elastic' effect.

The shape memory effect enables the use of SMAs in a wide range of technologies, from 'artificial muscles' that enable the controlled motion of machines (i. e. robots) without the use of servo motors; actuators capable of changing the shape of components in aerospace systems (wings,  jet engine chevrons) ; sensors capable of conveying information about the state of a given system or device by reacting to external stiumulus as well as systems capable of scavenging of otherwise waste energy, which in turn can contribute to improve energy efficiency in a wide range of technologies.

At the same time, the superelastic behavior of SMAs enables the use of SMAs in applications that require significant amounts of reversible deformation. The superelastic behavior of SMAs has enabled a wide range of technologies relevant to bioengineering, such as stents, hip and knee implants, etc.

Unfortunately, most SMAs are currently limited to operating temperatures below 100C, which limits their application at high temperatures. Recently, SMAs based on the Co-Ni-Ga alloy system have emerged as potentially economic and practical high-temperature SMAs (HTSMAs).

In this project, the PI (Raymundo Arroyave) and Co-PI (Ibrahim Karaman) worked on the development of novel Co-Ni-Ga alloys using a highly innovative computational+experimental approach, which is in line with the Materials Genome Initiative recently unveiled by the White House.

At the end of this project (three years and a half), the fololowing outcomes were achieved:

1. Scientific Outcomes:

a. Through this project we have identified the composition in the CoNiGa system with the highest temperature at which the reversible transformation (shape memory effect)  occurs.

b. We have also demonstrated that compositions in the CoNiGa system have the largest temperature range for superleastic behavior of any shape memory alloy studied today.

c. Through the combination of experiments and simulations, we have determined the phase diagram of the Co-Ni-Ga system. This phase diagram enables the further development of 'new recipes' for CoNiGa SMAs.

d. We have investihated the degradation mechanisms that limit the deployment of CoNiGa HTSMAs and have proposed strategies to alleviate them.

e. We have used simulation techniques based on quantum mechanics to explain the fundamental mechanisms for the phase transformations responsible for the shape memory behavior in CoNiGa HTSMAs.

f. Using experiments and simulations, we have determined, for the first time, the most important alloying (compositional) criteria that affect the temperature at which the reversible transformation takes place in these systems. These ideas can be extended to other novel SMAs.

g. More than fifteen scientific publications as well as  a dozen conference talks and invited talks in universities and research institutes have resulted from this work.

2. Broader Impacts

The PI and Co-PI are higly committed to the dissemination of science, particularly of materials science since many technological problems the US and the World currently face are ultimately related to materials. Through this project, the PI and Co-PI have been able to contribute to the dissemination and outreach mission of NSF. The following are some of the examples:

a. Five studentents (including a female and a Hispanic student) have been supported through this research. This has resulted in tw...
